entry.title: Final GSoC Report
entry.content:
Wait, august 19th? Where’s my summer? I feel like i just started this GSoC!

Alas, it’s already coming to an end. Those two month have been amazing. Let’s head back and summarize what I’ve been doing during this time.

1. The Proposal

When I felt I was going to pass my exams and thus was going to have an exams-free summer, I knew I had to seize the opportunity to try to be selected for a GSoC. I talked about it with Guillaume Desmottes and we got to the idea of my proposal.

I was really happy to be selected and looking forward to the end of my exams to start working.

2. The Work’s Beginning

Around mid june it was finally time to get started. As I stated in my first weekly report, I begun by fixing some bugs to get in touch with Empathy’s code base. I then ported empathy-nautilus-sendto to the RosterView instead of EmpathyContactChooser.

It’s worth noting that Guillaume’s work on the RosterView between my proposal and my work’s beginning quite modified the initial planning.

3. The Model

The next step of my work was one of the most important : I created empathy-roster-model and empathy-roster-model-manager and moved all the logic out of the view to the model. This took longer than what Guillaume and I thought initially, but it got merged into master around the beginning of august.

During the model’s development I created a new test app in which I created 2 views using the same model. This helped me understanding what goal Guillaume wanted me to achieve here.

4. The ModelAggregator

empathy-roster-model-manager worked great for Empathy but it was way too Empathy specific to be usable elsewhere. Since the ultimate goal of the project is to create a library that any project could use I created empathy-roster-model-aggregator, a new implementation of empathy-roster-model relying on FolksIndividualAggregator.

5. A New Internal Lib

Once empathy-roster-model-aggregator was done and working as it should, I moved the view, the model (along with model-aggregator, but not model-manager) and various needed tools like EmpathyRosterContact or EmpathyRosterGroup to a new directory inside Empathy’s tree.

This is one step closer to the goal of the external library.

6. Gtk-doc and GIR

If we want this library to be widely used along GNOME projects, it had to be documented. I therefore added gtk-doc to the project and wrote some doc.

Using Gobject-introspection was also one step in the roadmap. I discovered how gir functions, created EmpathyRoster-0.1.gir and wrote a small example test app in Python.

7. The Future

So, what’s left to do?

  • A part of my code has yet to be reviewed, Guillaume being on holidays.
  • The library should be moved out of Empathy’s tree.
  • The gir annotations should be completed to eliminate warnings.
  • There’s probably more doc to write.

8. The Asides

In addition to what I’ve already talked about I also worked on other things. One of the most tiring ones was idling on a lot of new IRC channels. I also fixed a few bugs in Empathy and worked on a patch for Folks.

Unlike what I feared, I found myself quite enjoying writing my Weekly Reports. It was a nice way to have to take time to evaluate the week’s productivity.

9. The Results

To sum things up, let’s say that :

  • My coding skills have dramatically improved
  • I finally contributed to Open Source Software
  • I’ve had the best conceivable summer job. Not once did I start to work feeling I “had to” (excepted maybe for the doc writing step, let’s be honest).
  • I’ve acquired more knowledge about the various aspects of software development (at least regarding GNOME softwares).
  • I’ve lost time on really stupid errors.
  • I’m quite satisfied of my work.
  • I have more IRC chans to idle on.
  • I plan to continue coding and contributing.

TL;DR: Amazing experience. 10/10, would do again.

entry.title: Weekly Report #7
entry.content:
After finishing my new EmpathyRosterModelAggregator implementation of the EmpathyRosterModel interface (aggregator branch in my github repo), I moved all the concerned files to a new directory to have them as a new private library ((libroster branch in my github repo)). This is still in Empathy’s tree, but it’s ready to be transformed as an external lib.

I then started writing documentation with gtk-doc (libroster-docs branch in my github repo). I lost a few days to get it working “thanks” to the fact that I passed –enable-gtk-docs to autogen.sh instead of –enable-gtk-doc. What a wonderful example of a PEBCAK error that can drive you insane.

I’m now going to finish the docs before trying to bind my library to GObject-Introspection. I’m also going to update my page on live.gnome.org and prepare my final GSoC blogpost.

Little spoiler about this blogpost: This GSoC has been an awesome experience.

entry.content:
As the title suggests, I’m on holidays in the French Alps. This doesn’t mean that my GSoC is on hold, but it means that I’m enjoying a beautifull sight while coding :

During this week, I’ve continued my work on EmpathyRosterModel and EmpathyRosterModelManager. The model now catches all the signals emitted by the manager previously catched by the view. It also now have all the functions needed to be able to completely rely on the model and remove every manager references in the view. As said in my previous post, all of this is pushed on github : lcontzen/empathy.

On a side note, I found out that if all your top contacts are offline the group name isn’t displayed and the top contacts are lost alone on the top of the roster. I reported it and submitted a patch fixing this behavior (bug #679868) (this still needs to be reviewed).

PS : Good news, everyone! I passed my Midterm Evaluation! \o/

entry.title: My GSoC Proposal
entry.content:
As mentionned before, I’ve been accepted to do a Google Summer of Code for GNOME. My proposal is about the creation of a new library providing models and widgets to display and choose contacts. For those who don’t want to read the complete proposal here are the interesting bits :

What is the ultimate goal of your proposal?

The ultimate goal of my proposal is to develop a new C library providing models and Gtk+ widgets to display and choose contacts that could be used by any GNOME application, a feature that Empathy’s developers are considering to implement since a long time. It has been discussed last year during the IM/Social Hackfest and some notes are available on the wiki.

The contact chooser would be integrable in a lot of GNOME application or plugins such as Nautilus-sendto, the Shell’s contact search engine, Evolution (which could begin to use Folks and allow to send mails to IM contacts), or any GNOME application which could benefit from IM integration using Telepathy tubes for example. The library will be usable in C, Python and Javascript thanks to the GObject Introspection support.

What components/modules will the proposed work modify or create?

A model of the loaded contacts will be developed and widgets will be built on top of it. This will be developed as a new library that other projects will be able to use. This library will probably be named Folks-gtk, but this name might change during the development if we find a cooler one. The API will mainly provide :
-Functionalities to fetch and display all contacts from Folks
-An API to define if one or more contacts can be picked
-An API to let the user filter out contacts
-Helper code for some common filters (like online contacts)

This will, obviously, be related to Empathy, Telepathy and Folks. To validate the library and its API, Empathy’s nautilus-sendto plugin will be modified to make use of it. If time permits, I’ll also modify Shell’s contact search feature to use it as well.

What benefits does your proposed work have for GNOME and its community?

  • IM integration and Telepathy tubes :
    This contact chooser I’m proposing to implement here would help improving IM’s integration in the whole GNOME desktop experience. Whatever the application is and whatever the developer wants to do involving IM contacts, he won’t have to think about the way to choose contacts or struggle implementing it. Of course, it’s not only valuable for developers but it’s also profitable for the end users since more applications could start offering more social features.
    Even if Telepathy tubes have been implemented several years ago they are only quite rarely used in GNOME. Vinagre/Vino use them for Empathy’s desktop sharing, a really popular and innovating feature, but that’s about it. There are at least two reasons which could explain this : the first is that tubes are quite difficult to use, and the second is the difficulty to fetch and present the list of contacts (needed in almost any application implementing social features). Telepathy’s team is working to fix the first problem (telepathy-glib now has high level tubes API) and my project would fix the second one.

  • Contacts coherence :
    Since GNOME 3.2, gnome-contacts defined a new way to display contacts in GNOME. Empathy’s developers are working with the design team to re-design Empathy’s contact list to make it more coherent with the rest of the desktop (see bug #669484). If more applications are going to integrate social features it’s important to stay coherent and offer a coherent way to display contacts in the whole GNOME desktop.
